title: How to like responsibility and what are the benefits of being responsible - Quora

response.answer_text: How can I like responsibility and what are the benefits of being responsible? First, let me say I had no choice to make decisions for myself when I was just “nine years old” and why? I didn't have parents that took their responsibility seriously even with five in a family. They lacked having decent jobs, so they could budget appropriately. Plus they gave us 50 cents per week for milk and desert which I only use part of that money to save for school supplies and to have a hot meal at the cafeteria once in a while. Secondly, when you take responsibility for your action you have a sense of accomplishment such as I was able to learn to iron my school uniform and polish my shoes without having to ask anyone to do it for me. It felt “wonderful” because I was motivated to do well in school, even if my parents could care less. I set myself to do well for the sake of my education and knew by the age of 11 that education was the “key” to a prosperous future. When I tried to explain that to my mom she refused to do her part to educate herself in learning the English Language - and this I know - that our existence was never going to get better because they refuse to do what it takes to be responsible adults. However, nothing was going to stop me and I even got a small errand job knocking on apartment doors where I live and asked if they needed anything at the store for me to pick up. I did get a few neighbors and got tips once I got home. I was by this time 10 years old trying to survive in a home that sometimes we didn’t have enough food for the week. For me responsibility should have been my middle name because I thrived in learning and understanding you get results when you work to do well not just in school but outside of school too.

Responsibility brings both power and fulfillment, which challenge and enrich us. Irresponsibility is normal for young children, but as a teenager or adult, you are part of a community, and your main responsibility is basic: contribute more than you deplete, and don’t harm or unnecessarily disrupt others. The unnecessarily part is important, since it is also a responsibility in a civilized society to help and protect those less fortunate or to whom an injustice has been done. A good way to feel the benefits of responsibility is to volunteer somewhere that is personally meaningful to you. It could be an animal shelter, a food bank, a political cause… where you will be granted responsibilities and will feel very tangibly the contribution you are making. It feels good, by the way. :)
